fr:title.text: Container Combinatorics: Monads and Lax Monoidal Functors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Container Combinatorics: Monads and Lax Monoidal Functors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Coproduct monad container for a set E is given by the data 1 + E \triangleright T where T\ (\text {inl}\ *) := 1, T\ (\text {inr}\ \_) := 0 and: \begin {align*} \iota &:= \text {inl}\ *\\ \sigma \ (\text {inl}\ *)\ f &:= f\ *\\ \sigma \ (\text {inr}\ e)\ f &:= \text {inr}\ e\\ \text {pr}\ * &:= (* , *) \end {align*} This is the unique monad container structure that you can give the container 1 + E \triangleright T [uustalu2017]. This also happens to be a cartesian monad container. \text {pr} is well-defined up to function extensionality by induction on its implicit arguments.

Let S \triangleright P be a container. A monad container (or mnd-container) [uustalu2017] on S \triangleright P is given by the following data: \begin {align*} \iota &: S\\ \sigma &: \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to S) \to S\\ \text {pr} &: \prod _{\{s : S\}} \prod _{\{f : P\ s \to S\}} P\ (\sigma \ s\ f) \to \sum _{p : P\ s} P\ (f\ p) \end {align*} For which the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ \iota \ (\lambda \_ . a ) &= a\\ \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ) &= a\\ \sigma \ (\sigma \ a\ f)\ (\lambda p . g\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\ (\text {pr}_2\ p)) &= \sigma \ a\ (\lambda p . \sigma \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p))\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_1\ p) &= \text {pr}_1\ p\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) \end {align*} We abbreviate \pi _1 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_1 and \pi _2 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_2. The last three laws hold up to the "associativity" law for \sigma .
